These data are updated regularly. Historic alignments have the original trail segment IDs except in a few cases. Historic trail segment IDs with a decimal in the .90s either had a different trail ID (not segment ID); others had a trail segment ID that matched one that was used in the 2006-2007 trail condition inventory. I didn't change the 2006-7 ID because it would be overly complicated to change all items relating to a new segment ID.

Wildlife closure areas with date range and type of closure. EnactedClosure attribute must equal "Yes" and current date must fall between the Date_From and Date_To fields (replacing year in these fields with appropriate year(s)). Includes Raptor, Grassland Birds, Bats, and Invasive Species. This data is updated from OSMPGIS to GISPROD on the first day of each month. It replaces the data found in WildlifeClosures.

The lakes and reservoirs in this dataset were conflated from various data sources, including NHD, Colorado Department of Natural Resources Division of Water Resources (CDSS), Boulder County, City of Boulder and individual ditch companies. The data was verified with field visits and extensive staff knowledge. The data includes links to various internal databases, as well as the Colorado Division of Water Resources database. Pre and Post 2013 Colorado Flood alignments are included. This data is appropriate for both small and large scale usage.

Pre and Post 2013 Colorado Flood alignments are included. Flow directions for network analysis are also incorporated into the data. This data is appropriate for both small and large scale usage.

layers.description: These data represent OSMP's designated trails. All trails in this dataset are also managed by OSMP, even though some trails are actually owned by other agencies. Some trails are considered sensitive and are not displayed to the public. Use the 'Display' field to show or not show these trails; Display = 'Yes' will only display those trails that are okay to show to the public. Archived data exist and can be queried out using the 'DateFrom' and 'DateTo' fields. To show only those trails that are currently designated and to remove the network connectors (which are not real trails), use the following definition query:  CURRENT_TIMESTAMP between DateFrom and DateTo and Name <> 'Network Connector Segment'

The trails included in this dataset are owned and/or operated by Boulder County.

The query should be used at all times.Data can also be broken down into classes using the 'Class' field.T1: Simple/Minor Developed Trailhead - Very Low Use T2: Developed/Improved Trailhead - Medium Use T3: Full Developed Trailhead - High to Very High Use A1: Access to Trails - Very Low Use A2: Access to Trails Meduim - High Use A3: Access to Trails Very High Use R1: Provides no designated traill Access. For 2012 Data:  This contains point features that describe the location and type of constructed features along undesignated trails and roads on Open Space and Mountain Park managed lands. Points were GPS-mapped in the field between July 2011 and November 2012 as part of the system-wide undesignated trail mapping project. Points show the location of constructed features such as culverts, steps, and retaining walls that have some effect on visitor travel along the undesignated pathway. Constructed feature types were chosen from categories in the GPS data dictionary and correspond to categories used for mapping constructed features during the system-wide designated trail condition monitoring. Details on constructed feature mapping methods and category descriptions can be found in the 2011/2012 system-wide undesignated trail mapping protocol available upon request to the Environmental Planning group.

UT_Road_barriers_2012 is a point feature file describing the location and type of road barriers on undesignated roads on OSMP managed lands. Road barriers were GPS-mapped in the field at the location where access to an otherwise drivable road was blocked. Mapping occurred between July 2011 and November 2012 as part of the 2011/2012 system-wide undesignated trail mapping project. Methods for mapping road barriers and descriptions of type of road barriers are detailed in the 2011/2012 undesignated trail mapping protocol available upon request to the Environmental Planning group.
This is the merged or grouped version of the original data. New UDTs are to be added to this file as they are mapped in the field. No new UDT data has been added as of 3/16/2015.

layers.description: From Andy Pelster regarding maintenance: "In most cases OSMP has management responsibility for fences on fee owned properties. If we build a boundary fence that joins a private property, OSMP will typically build the fence on the OSMP side of the boundary. If there is a cost-share agreement between both parties the fence will be built on the surveyed boundary line. Easement fencing responsibilities are generally dictated by the conservation easement language, so it is a mixed bag."Field descriptions:EXTERIOR – Designates whether or not a particular length of fence in question separates OSMP fee managed property from private land, other public lands or conservation easements. . Because this attribute was interpreted mostly in terms of the movement of livestock, if the fence did not fall directly on the property line but was the only barrier to prevent movement of animals from one type of property to another, the features was marked as exterior.CONDITION – Based primarily on the ability of the gate to keep livestock from passing through, not on the ability of the gate to open and close.INVYEAR – Year in which the particular feature was inventoried.COMMENTS:For GATETYPE Stile – the material used or type of stile is listed hereFor GATETYPE Opening – size of the opening is noted (generally ‘vehicle’ or ‘pedestrian’). Also contains notes regarding the nature of the opening.

From Andy Pelster regarding maintenance: "In most cases OSMP has management responsibility for fences on fee owned properties. If we build a boundary fence that joins a private property, OSMP will typically build the fence on the OSMP side of the boundary. If there is a cost-share agreement between both parties the fence will be built on the surveyed boundary line. Easement fencing responsibilities are generally dictated by the conservation easement language, so it is a mixed bag."Below are the field descriptions:EXTERIOR – Designates whether or not a particular length of fence in question separates OSMP fee managed property from private land, other public lands or conservation easements. Because this attribute was interpreted mostly in terms of the movement of livestock, if the fence did not fall directly on the property line but was the only barrier to prevent movement of animals from one type of property to another, the feature was marked as exterior.FENCETYPE: the vast majority of features fall into one of the prescribed values, but in the cases were a length of fence incorporates more than one type of fencing the following system is used to describe the feature:The FENCETYPE field itself is used to describe the primary material used in the fence construction. Secondary fencing types are delineated using a 3 part, 4 character alphanumeric code that follows this pattern #AAA [one digit followed by 3 letters]. The number indicates the number of strands in question [1-9]The next two letters indicate the fence type.sw = Smooth Wirebw = Barbed Wireht = High TensileI think those are the only instances The final letter describes where the strands are positioned on the fence.t = Topmost strandb = Bottommost Strandm = Somewhere in the MiddleFOR EXAMPLE: a common occurrence in the South TSA is a 4 strand fence where the top strand is barbed and the bottom 3 are smooth. Because barbed wire is of particular concern where wildlife is concerned, the FENCETYPE field is marked “Barbed Wire”. The STRANDS field is “4” and the COMMENTS field contains the code: “1bwt, 3swb” indicating that the top strand is barbed while the bottom 3 are smooth.Clear as mud? Good. Moving along, then.CONDITION – This field is judged principally on the basis of whether or not the fence would be able to keep livestock on one side or the other. The beginning and end points of sections marked as “disrepair” are generally accurate to within ~25 feet, though on some occasions an entire segment will be marked as “disrepair” when there are actually some lengths of the fence that are still standing and in good shape.COMMENTS: PLASTIC – High Tensile fencing equipped with spacers made of plastic rather than wood have the word ‘PLASTIC’ in the comments field.down/> down/>standing – for fences that were badly damaged and often apparently abandoned, these designations were used to further elaborate on their condition. “down” indicates that the entire length of fence, including the fence posts have succumbed to gravity and are lying on the ground. “> down” indicates that mostof the fencing material, including posts, are down on the ground. “> standing” indicates that while the fence is definitely in disrepair, it is for the most part still standing and easily identified as a fence rather than evidence of some kind of illegal barbed wire dumping activity.empty fence posts – fencing material (such as barbed wire) has been removed, leaving only standing fence posts.RESTORATION – Predominantly 20’ – 50’ lengths of rim and rail type fence used to keep visitors (not livestock) off of recently restored or otherwise sensitive areas.snow fence/knapweed – indicates sections of fencing not intended to control livestock but to limit the movement of snow and/or knapweed* Features of the ‘Flood Gate’ FENCETYPE should have the material used to construct the flood gate noted in the COMMENTS field. This field also used to describe the type and condition of prairie dog fencing.PDOG_FENCE – This field is used to indicate whether or not the given length of fence includes prairie dog fencing in addition to the primary fencing type. Condition and material used are indicated in the COMMENT field.SMOOTHTOP – Used primarily to indicate whether the top strand of a barbed wire fence is made of smooth wire. Chainlink and field fence types also received ‘No’ values if the particular length of fence had jagged or sharp protrusions along the top.GRND2TOP – Indicates whether or not the average distance between the top of the fence and the ground is less than/equal to 42”, or greater than 42”.INVYEAR – Year in which the particular feature was inventoried.SMOOTHBOT – Same as SMOOTHTOP, only refers to the bottom strand or edge of fence. Also, indicates the presence or absences of a particularly socially adept automaton known as Smooth Bot.GRND2BOT – Indicates whether or not the average distance between the ground and the bottom of the fence is greater than/equal to 16” or less than 16”.STRANDS – number of strands used in the length of fence. ‘0’ values are used for ‘empty fence posts’ where no obvious fencing is present and for FENCETYPES where strand count does not make apply, such as Chainlink and Field.

The streams and ditches in this dataset were conflated from various data sources, including NHD, Colorado Department of Natural Resources Division of Water Resources (CDSS), Boulder County, City of Boulder and individual ditch companies. layers.description: These data represent all properties that OSMP has an interest in, regardless of type of interest, whether another entity also has an interest or who is the managing entity. The data that makes these distinctions is contained in the 'TYPE', 'JOINTPURCH' and 'Manager' fields respectively.AcqID is used to link to a seperate SQL database containing more detailed information about property purchases. PropertyID is unique to single properties which may be comprised of multiple features while PolyID is unique to individual features.Typically, public-facing maps include only properties with the 'Fee Property' value.Care should be taken when using this dataset in conjunction with other public land datasets so as to avoid unintentional feature overlaps or duplication.

Easement fencing responsibilities are generally dictated by the conservation easement language, so it is a mixed bag."Field descriptions:EXTERIOR – Designates whether or not a particular length of fence in question separates OSMP fee managed property from private land, other public lands or conservation easements. . Because this attribute was interpreted mostly in terms of the movement of livestock, if the fence did not fall directly on the property line but was the only barrier to prevent movement of animals from one type of property to another, the features was marked as exterior.CONDITION – Based primarily on the ability of the gate to keep livestock from passing through, not on the ability of the gate to open and close.INVYEAR – Year in which the particular feature was inventoried.COMMENTS:For GATETYPE Stile – the material used or type of stile is listed hereFor GATETYPE Opening – size of the opening is noted (generally ‘vehicle’ or ‘pedestrian’). Also contains notes regarding the nature of the opening.

From Andy Pelster regarding maintenance: "In most cases OSMP has management responsibility for fences on fee owned properties. If we build a boundary fence that joins a private property, OSMP will typically build the fence on the OSMP side of the boundary. If there is a cost-share agreement between both parties the fence will be built on the surveyed boundary line. Easement fencing responsibilities are generally dictated by the conservation easement language, so it is a mixed bag."Below are the field descriptions:EXTERIOR – Designates whether or not a particular length of fence in question separates OSMP fee managed property from private land, other public lands or conservation easements. Because this attribute was interpreted mostly in terms of the movement of livestock, if the fence did not fall directly on the property line but was the only barrier to prevent movement of animals from one type of property to another, the feature was marked as exterior.FENCETYPE: the vast majority of features fall into one of the prescribed values, but in the cases were a length of fence incorporates more than one type of fencing the following system is used to describe the feature:The FENCETYPE field itself is used to describe the primary material used in the fence construction. Secondary fencing types are delineated using a 3 part, 4 character alphanumeric code that follows this pattern #AAA [one digit followed by 3 letters]. The number indicates the number of strands in question [1-9]The next two letters indicate the fence type.sw = Smooth Wirebw = Barbed Wireht = High TensileI think those are the only instances The final letter describes where the strands are positioned on the fence.t = Topmost strandb = Bottommost Strandm = Somewhere in the MiddleFOR EXAMPLE: a common occurrence in the South TSA is a 4 strand fence where the top strand is barbed and the bottom 3 are smooth. Because barbed wire is of particular concern where wildlife is concerned, the FENCETYPE field is marked “Barbed Wire”. The STRANDS field is “4” and the COMMENTS field contains the code: “1bwt, 3swb” indicating that the top strand is barbed while the bottom 3 are smooth.Clear as mud? Good. Moving along, then.CONDITION – This field is judged principally on the basis of whether or not the fence would be able to keep livestock on one side or the other. The beginning and end points of sections marked as “disrepair” are generally accurate to within ~25 feet, though on some occasions an entire segment will be marked as “disrepair” when there are actually some lengths of the fence that are still standing and in good shape.COMMENTS: PLASTIC – High Tensile fencing equipped with spacers made of plastic rather than wood have the word ‘PLASTIC’ in the comments field.down/> down/>standing – for fences that were badly damaged and often apparently abandoned, these designations were used to further elaborate on their condition. “down” indicates that the entire length of fence, including the fence posts have succumbed to gravity and are lying on the ground. “> down” indicates that mostof the fencing material, including posts, are down on the ground. “> standing” indicates that while the fence is definitely in disrepair, it is for the most part still standing and easily identified as a fence rather than evidence of some kind of illegal barbed wire dumping activity.empty fence posts – fencing material (such as barbed wire) has been removed, leaving only standing fence posts.RESTORATION – Predominantly 20’ – 50’ lengths of rim and rail type fence used to keep visitors (not livestock) off of recently restored or otherwise sensitive areas.snow fence/knapweed – indicates sections of fencing not intended to control livestock but to limit the movement of snow and/or knapweed* Features of the ‘Flood Gate’ FENCETYPE should have the material used to construct the flood gate noted in the COMMENTS field. This field also used to describe the type and condition of prairie dog fencing.PDOG_FENCE – This field is used to indicate whether or not the given length of fence includes prairie dog fencing in addition to the primary fencing type. Condition and material used are indicated in the COMMENT field.SMOOTHTOP – Used primarily to indicate whether the top strand of a barbed wire fence is made of smooth wire. Chainlink and field fence types also received ‘No’ values if the particular length of fence had jagged or sharp protrusions along the top.GRND2TOP – Indicates whether or not the average distance between the top of the fence and the ground is less than/equal to 42”, or greater than 42”.INVYEAR – Year in which the particular feature was inventoried.SMOOTHBOT – Same as SMOOTHTOP, only refers to the bottom strand or edge of fence. Also, indicates the presence or absences of a particularly socially adept automaton known as Smooth Bot.GRND2BOT – Indicates whether or not the average distance between the ground and the bottom of the fence is greater than/equal to 16” or less than 16”.STRANDS – number of strands used in the length of fence. ‘0’ values are used for ‘empty fence posts’ where no obvious fencing is present and for FENCETYPES where strand count does not make apply, such as Chainlink and Field.

The streams and ditches in this dataset were conflated from various data sources, including NHD, Colorado Department of Natural Resources Division of Water Resources (CDSS), Boulder County, City of Boulder and individual ditch companies. The data was verified with field visits and extensive staff knowledge. The data includes links to various internal databases, as well as the Colorado Division of Water Resources database. Pre and Post 2013 Colorado Flood alignments are included. Flow directions for network analysis are also incorporated into the data. This data is appropriate for both small and large scale usage.

This point feature class is the best representation of rock climbing formations on the City of Boulder's Open Space and Mountain Parks' property. Some of thiese formations fall within areas that are seasonally closed to protect nesting and roosting raptors.

layers.description: Data contained in this file shows all designated THs, APs and ARFs.  Two access points (Old Mesa and Lion''s Lair at Sunshine Canyon) are sensitive data and should not be displayed to the public. There are also several access points in this dataset that have not been officially designated yet. They have an 'AccessID' of '1003', '1004 and '1005' and are excluded from the dataset along with archived data using the following query:  CURRENT_TIMESTAMP between DateFrom and DateTo. The query should be used at all times.Data can also be broken down into classes using the 'Class' field.T1: Simple/Minor Developed Trailhead - Very Low Use T2: Developed/Improved Trailhead - Medium Use T3: Full Developed Trailhead - High to Very High Use A1: Access to Trails - Very Low Use A2: Access to Trails Meduim - High Use A3: Access to Trails Very High Use R1: Provides no designated traill Access. Includes Picnic Areas, viewpoints and bench sites - Low to Medium use R2: Provides no designated traill Access. Includes Picnic Areas, viewpoints and bench sites - High to Very High use

For 2012 Data:  This contains point features that describe the location and type of constructed features along undesignated trails and roads on Open Space and Mountain Park managed lands. Points were GPS-mapped in the field between July 2011 and November 2012 as part of the system-wide undesignated trail mapping project. Points show the location of constructed features such as culverts, steps, and retaining walls that have some effect on visitor travel along the undesignated pathway. Constructed feature types were chosen from categories in the GPS data dictionary and correspond to categories used for mapping constructed features during the system-wide designated trail condition monitoring. Details on constructed feature mapping methods and category descriptions can be found in the 2011/2012 system-wide undesignated trail mapping protocol available upon request to the Environmental Planning group.

UT_Road_barriers_2012 is a point feature file describing the location and type of road barriers on undesignated roads on OSMP managed lands. Road barriers were GPS-mapped in the field at the location where access to an otherwise drivable road was blocked. Mapping occurred between July 2011 and November 2012 as part of the 2011/2012 system-wide undesignated trail mapping project. Methods for mapping road barriers and descriptions of type of road barriers are detailed in the 2011/2012 undesignated trail mapping protocol available upon request to the Environmental Planning group.
This is the merged or grouped version of the original data. New UDTs are to be added to this file as they are mapped in the field. No new UDT data has been added as of 3/16/2015.

layers.description: These data represent all properties that OSMP has an interest in, regardless of type of interest, whether another entity also has an interest or who is the managing entity. layers.description: Providing OSMP and other Emergency Personnel detailed sensitive information of all driveable access roads in and around OSMP lands. Roads are classified into four criteria based on ease of access. Information source includes USGS, Boulder County, and City of Boulder Open Space and Mountain Parks GIS data. Roads are classified 1 if they are paved, gravel, and wide. Class 2 is more narrow, steep, bumpy and moderately severe. Class 3 represents severe conditions may exist like narrow byways over steep terrain, unmarked roadways, tree and rockway blockage or loose rock. The most severe classification is ranked 4 and represents the most treacherous terrain conditions for driving. Printed maps and GIS data from OSMP (Potential Emergency Access Routes Working Map, City of Boulder, Colorado, Open Space), USGS, and BOCO are merged into one dataset and duplicates are removed with some roadways digitized from 2010 Dr. Cog aerial imagery where missing data was not included in original feature class.

These data represent OSMP's designated trails. All trails in this dataset are also managed by OSMP, even though some trails are actually owned by other agencies. Some trails are considered sensitive and are not displayed to the public. Use the 'Display' field to show or not show these trails; Display = 'Yes' will only display those trails that are okay to show to the public. Archived data exist and can be queried out using the 'DateFrom' and 'DateTo' fields. To show only those trails that are currently designated and to remove the network connectors (which are not real trails), use the following definition query:  CURRENT_TIMESTAMP between DateFrom and DateTo and Name <> 'Network Connector Segment'
This is the merged or grouped version of the original data. New UDTs are to be added to this file as they are mapped in the field. No new UDT data has been added as of 3/16/2015.

layers.description: Management Areas designated as: Habitat Conservation Areas (HCA), Natural Areas (NA), Passive Recreation Areas (PRA), or Agricultural Areas in the 2005 Visitor Master Plan (VMP). Updated in 2008 to include new property acquisitions - these are desiganted as TBD (to be determined pending new property plans).1-23-2013 Attribute "MZD" represents the Management Zone Designation assigned in the SDE.Planning.Management Designation Areas feature class where AA is Agricultural Area, PRA is Passive Recreation Area, HCA is Habitat Conservation Area, and NA is Natural Area. Conditional MZD awaiting Board of Trustees and City Council approval is noted as AG_C, PRA_C, HCA_C, and NA_C. Null values in MZD represent non existent management designation and TBD is to be determined. NONE may represent no management designation per misc easements and where properties may belong to someone else, therefore the MZD is undetermined. Where properties have multiple management areas the MZD attribute notes the categories alphabetically seperated by slash marks, eg. HCA/NA/PRA. This attribute allows query and spatial connectivity of management designation areas as assigned to each property and will eventually link a many to many relationship through the field PropNum, the future spatial connection between properties and management designation zones. Kathy Metivier GIS Technician.

layers.description: From Andy Pelster regarding maintenance: "In most cases OSMP has management responsibility for fences on fee owned properties. If we build a boundary fence that joins a private property, OSMP will typically build the fence on the OSMP side of the boundary. If there is a cost-share agreement between both parties the fence will be built on the surveyed boundary line. Easement fencing responsibilities are generally dictated by the conservation easement language, so it is a mixed bag."Below are the field descriptions:EXTERIOR – Designates whether or not a particular length of fence in question separates OSMP fee managed property from private land, other public lands or conservation easements. Because this attribute was interpreted mostly in terms of the movement of livestock, if the fence did not fall directly on the property line but was the only barrier to prevent movement of animals from one type of property to another, the feature was marked as exterior.FENCETYPE: the vast majority of features fall into one of the prescribed values, but in the cases were a length of fence incorporates more than one type of fencing the following system is used to describe the feature:The FENCETYPE field itself is used to describe the primary material used in the fence construction. Secondary fencing types are delineated using a 3 part, 4 character alphanumeric code that follows this pattern #AAA [one digit followed by 3 letters]. The number indicates the number of strands in question [1-9]The next two letters indicate the fence type.sw = Smooth Wirebw = Barbed Wireht = High TensileI think those are the only instances The final letter describes where the strands are positioned on the fence.t = Topmost strandb = Bottommost Strandm = Somewhere in the MiddleFOR EXAMPLE: a common occurrence in the South TSA is a 4 strand fence where the top strand is barbed and the bottom 3 are smooth. Because barbed wire is of particular concern where wildlife is concerned, the FENCETYPE field is marked “Barbed Wire”. The STRANDS field is “4” and the COMMENTS field contains the code: “1bwt, 3swb” indicating that the top strand is barbed while the bottom 3 are smooth.Clear as mud? Good. Moving along, then.CONDITION – This field is judged principally on the basis of whether or not the fence would be able to keep livestock on one side or the other. The beginning and end points of sections marked as “disrepair” are generally accurate to within ~25 feet, though on some occasions an entire segment will be marked as “disrepair” when there are actually some lengths of the fence that are still standing and in good shape.COMMENTS: PLASTIC – High Tensile fencing equipped with spacers made of plastic rather than wood have the word ‘PLASTIC’ in the comments field.down/> down/>standing – for fences that were badly damaged and often apparently abandoned, these designations were used to further elaborate on their condition. “down” indicates that the entire length of fence, including the fence posts have succumbed to gravity and are lying on the ground. “> down” indicates that mostof the fencing material, including posts, are down on the ground. “> standing” indicates that while the fence is definitely in disrepair, it is for the most part still standing and easily identified as a fence rather than evidence of some kind of illegal barbed wire dumping activity.empty fence posts – fencing material (such as barbed wire) has been removed, leaving only standing fence posts.RESTORATION – Predominantly 20’ – 50’ lengths of rim and rail type fence used to keep visitors (not livestock) off of recently restored or otherwise sensitive areas.snow fence/knapweed – indicates sections of fencing not intended to control livestock but to limit the movement of snow and/or knapweed* Features of the ‘Flood Gate’ FENCETYPE should have the material used to construct the flood gate noted in the COMMENTS field. This field also used to describe the type and condition of prairie dog fencing.PDOG_FENCE – This field is used to indicate whether or not the given length of fence includes prairie dog fencing in addition to the primary fencing type. Condition and material used are indicated in the COMMENT field.SMOOTHTOP – Used primarily to indicate whether the top strand of a barbed wire fence is made of smooth wire. Chainlink and field fence types also received ‘No’ values if the particular length of fence had jagged or sharp protrusions along the top.GRND2TOP – Indicates whether or not the average distance between the top of the fence and the ground is less than/equal to 42”, or greater than 42”.INVYEAR – Year in which the particular feature was inventoried.SMOOTHBOT – Same as SMOOTHTOP, only refers to the bottom strand or edge of fence. Also, indicates the presence or absences of a particularly socially adept automaton known as Smooth Bot.GRND2BOT – Indicates whether or not the average distance between the ground and the bottom of the fence is greater than/equal to 16” or less than 16”.STRANDS – number of strands used in the length of fence. ‘0’ values are used for ‘empty fence posts’ where no obvious fencing is present and for FENCETYPES where strand count does not make apply, such as Chainlink and Field.

layers.description: Data for the goat monitoring project are collected from both vegetation cover transects and chicory density plots, randomly located within a goat grazed area (grazed approximately every two years) and an area without goat grazing. The control and goat treatment subareas were subjectively chosen for their similar vegetation composition and land use history (including regular spring grazing by cattle). Within each sampling subarea, locations of six transect origins and 30 density plotcorners (southwest corners) were randomly selected using a simple random sampling tool implemented in ArcGIS. Monitoring for both chicory density and vegetation compositionoccurs each year prior to goat grazing in the 3rdand 4rth weeks of July. Details about the sampling design, monitoring objectives and field procedures can be found in the project protocol. The twelve goat monitoring transects are used to evaluate the richness of native and nonnative plant species, the percent cover of plant species, and the percent cover of substrates (bare ground, rock, litter). The 50-meter transect end points are marked in the field using rebar topped with labeled aluminum caps. Each transect is sampled by identifying the species or substrate directly beneath the cross hairs of an optical scope arm extended 1 meter on both sides of the transect line at 1 m intervals. All species observed within a 2 m wide belt transect on both sides of the transect are also listed to derive species richness. Oblique photographs are taken along each transect looking from the transect origin towards the end point to qualitatively document the condition of the vegetation. The 60 chicory density plots are used to monitor changes in chicory density within 2.0 m x 0.5 m plots. The southwest and northwest corners are marked in the field with aluminum washers secured with 6” penny nails. During sampling, all green chicory rosettes and reproductive stems within a rectangular PVC sampling frame are tallied.

mxd.description:
Description

Management Areas designated as: Habitat Conservation Areas (HCA), Natural Areas (NA), Passive Recreation Areas (PRA), or Agricultural Areas (AA) in the 2005 Visitor Master Plan (VMP). Continuously updated as plans are approved for newly acquired properties.Management areas awaiting Board of Trustees and City Council approval are noted with ' - Conditional' suffix. TBD is to be determined. From the VMP: "Management area designations define a management emphasis for different areas within the Open Space and Mountain Parks land system, based on a primary open space purpose (e.g., provision of quality passive recreational opportunities, preservation of agriculture, and protection and restoration of natural systems). The management designation defines suitable visitor activities in each type of area and under what conditions those activities can occur. The management designation also defines the management strategies needed to enhance visitor experience and ensure compatability of visitor activities with resource protetion. [...] The set of strategies applied in a given management area is based on the land characteristics (e.g., physical and ecological qualities, existing and anticipated visitor use patterns, existing and potential visitor infrastructure, and others) and the management needs that exist in that area."
mxd.tags: OSMP, Management Area Designations, City of Boulder
mxd.summary: Management designations areas on City of Boulder OSMP lands.

layers.description: OSMP Fee and Easement Properties (TYPE 6, 7, 9): These data represent all properties that OSMP has an interest in, regardless of type of interest, whether another entity also has an interest or who is the managing entity. The values that make these distinctions are contained in the 'TYPE', 'JOINTPURCH' and 'Manager' fields respectively. AcqID is used to link to a seperate SQL database containing more detailed information about property purchases. PropertyID is unique to single properties which may be comprised of multiple features while PolyID is unique to individual features. Typically, public-facing or general use maps include only properties with the 'Fee Property' value. Care should be taken when using this dataset in conjunction with other public land datasets so as to avoid unintentional feature overlaps or duplication.OSMP Management Area Designations (TYPE 5): Management Areas designated as: Habitat Conservation Areas (HCA), Natural Areas (NA), Passive Recreation Areas (PRA), or Agricultural Areas (AA) in the 2005 Visitor Master Plan (VMP). Continuously updated as plans are approved for newly acquired properties. Management areas awaiting Board of Trustees and City Council approval are noted with ' - Conditional' suffix. TBD is to be determined.From the VMP: "Management area designations define a management emphasis for different areas within the Open Space and Mountain Parks land system, based on a primary open space purpose (e.g., provision of quality passive recreational opportunities, preservation of agriculture, and protection and restoration of natural systems). The management designation defines suitable visitor activities in each type of area and under what conditions those activities can occur. The management designation also defines the management strategies needed to enhance visitor experience and ensure compatability of visitor activities with resource protetion. [...] The set of strategies applied in a given management area is based on the land characteristics (e.g., physical and ecological qualities, existing and anticipated visitor use patterns, existing and potential visitor infrastructure, and others) and the management needs that exist in that area."PLSS Township, Section, Quarter Section and Quarter Quarter Section (TYPE 1, 2, 3, 12): these data were not created and are not maintained by the city of Boulder

layers.description: This dataset contains US National Vegetation Classification data, in a heirarchical format. OSMP maintains threee levels in the hierarchy: Subclass, Alliance and Association. The Sublass is roughly equivalent to Ecosystem level data, while the Association data is equivalent to a vegetation "community". The target level for mapping on OSMP is the Alliance. While most of the Alliances and Associations are recognized by NatureServe , some are provisional types that have been created by OSMP to represent unique vegetation types that are not yet recognized within the USNVC.

mxd.description:
Non editable feature service for use as background layer to be consumed by Collector and other clients. Data is drawn from the RAM_Pt SDE feature class.

RAM data consists of a full inventory of a particular area, while ORP data are collected as the field staff spots the occurrences. 

You can determine what type of data features are and what year they were collected in by looking at the 'Project' column. RAM is rapid assessment mapping for IPM species while performing a complete inventory of an area or OSMP property. ORP data are collected using RAM methods, except that complete inventories were not performed. Each point represents the center point of the plants for each species and the size of the area covered by the species. Generalized, circular polygons can be created using the "Buffer_ft" field. Data are upated annually.

layers.description: These data represent OSMP's designated trails. All trails in this dataset are also managed by OSMP, even though some trails are actually owned by other agencies. Some trails are considered sensitive and are not displayed to the public. Use the 'Display' field to show or not show these trails; Display = 'Yes' will only display those trails that are okay to show to the public. Archived data exist and can be queried out using the 'DateFrom' and 'DateTo' fields. To show only those trails that are currently designated and to remove the network connectors (which are not real trails), use the following definition query:  CURRENT_TIMESTAMP between DateFrom and DateTo and Name <> 'Network Connector Segment'

Updated in 2008 to include new property acquisitions - these are desiganted as TBD (to be determined pending new property plans).1-23-2013 Attribute "MZD" represents the Management Zone Designation assigned in the SDE.Planning.Management Designation Areas feature class where AA is Agricultural Area, PRA is Passive Recreation Area, HCA is Habitat Conservation Area, and NA is Natural Area. Conditional MZD awaiting Board of Trustees and City Council approval is noted as AG_C, PRA_C, HCA_C, and NA_C. Null values in MZD represent non existent management designation and TBD is to be determined. NONE may represent no management designation per misc easements and where properties may belong to someone else, therefore the MZD is undetermined. Where properties have multiple management areas the MZD attribute notes the categories alphabetically seperated by slash marks, eg. HCA/NA/PRA. This attribute allows query and spatial connectivity of management designation areas as assigned to each property and will eventually link a many to many relationship through the field PropNum, the future spatial connection between properties and management designation zones. Kathy Metivier GIS Technician.

layers.description: These data represent OSMP's designated trails. All trails in this dataset are also managed by OSMP, even though some trails are actually owned by other agencies. In general, each trail has been broken up into segments, usually between junctions. The unique ID for each trail segment is within the "RID" field, which is unique over time. This means the RID of a trail segment can change over time, for example when a new alignment occurs. Each trail segment has a unique ID, within the "SegmentID" field, that never changes over time.All trails are routes and have directionality and measures associated with them. These data represent OSMP's designated trails. All trails in this dataset are also managed by OSMP, even though some trails are actually owned by other agencies. 
In general, each trail has been broken up into segments, usually between junctions. The unique ID for each trail segment is within the "RID" field, which is unique over time. This means the RID of a trail segment can change over time, for example when a new alignment occurs. Each trail segment has a unique ID, within the "SegmentID" field, that never changes over time.
All trails are routes and have directionality and measures associated with them. The measures are based on the field measured trail length. Field measured trail length is stored in the "MeasuredFeet" field and GIS trail length is stored in the "shape.length" field. Currently the "Mileage" field is based on GIS trail length and not the field measured length. These data are topologically connected to the Trail Junctions feature class.
Trail mileage labels display the distance between trail intersection points

UT_Road_barriers_2012 is a point feature file describing the location and type of road barriers on undesignated roads on OSMP managed lands. Road barriers were GPS-mapped in the field at the location where access to an otherwise drivable road was blocked. Mapping occurred between July 2011 and November 2012 as part of the 2011/2012 system-wide undesignated trail mapping project. Methods for mapping road barriers and descriptions of type of road barriers are detailed in the 2011/2012 undesignated trail mapping protocol available upon request to the Environmental Planning group.

For 2012 Data:  This contains point features that describe the location and type of constructed features along undesignated trails and roads on Open Space and Mountain Park managed lands. Points were GPS-mapped in the field between July 2011 and November 2012 as part of the system-wide undesignated trail mapping project. Points show the location of constructed features such as culverts, steps, and retaining walls that have some effect on visitor travel along the undesignated pathway. Constructed feature types were chosen from categories in the GPS data dictionary and correspond to categories used for mapping constructed features during the system-wide designated trail condition monitoring. Details on constructed feature mapping methods and category descriptions can be found in the 2011/2012 system-wide undesignated trail mapping protocol available upon request to the Environmental Planning group.
This is the merged or grouped version of the original data. New UDTs are to be added to this file as they are mapped in the field. No new UDT data has been added as of 3/16/2015.

Management Areas designated as: Habitat Conservation Areas (HCA), Natural Areas (NA), Passive Recreation Areas (PRA), or Agricultural Areas in the 2005 Visitor Master Plan (VMP). Updated in 2008 to include new property acquisitions - these are desiganted as TBD (to be determined pending new property plans).1-23-2013 Attribute "MZD" represents the Management Zone Designation assigned in the SDE.Planning.Management Designation Areas feature class where AA is Agricultural Area, PRA is Passive Recreation Area, HCA is Habitat Conservation Area, and NA is Natural Area. Conditional MZD awaiting Board of Trustees and City Council approval is noted as AG_C, PRA_C, HCA_C, and NA_C. Null values in MZD represent non existent management designation and TBD is to be determined. NONE may represent no management designation per misc easements and where properties may belong to someone else, therefore the MZD is undetermined. Where properties have multiple management areas the MZD attribute notes the categories alphabetically seperated by slash marks, eg. HCA/NA/PRA. This attribute allows query and spatial connectivity of management designation areas as assigned to each property and will eventually link a many to many relationship through the field PropNum, the future spatial connection between properties and management designation zones. Kathy Metivier GIS Technician.

mxd.description: Horticulture assets represent spatially defined and managed plant beds or planned rock beds that are not intended to be paths.  These beds may include annual and/or perennial plants, shrubs, trees, or a mixture of plant types.  Areas of native or natural vegetation that are confined to small areas and that are managed with other uses of adjacent assets in mind, such as pockets of vegetation along greenways, should be classified in the Horticulture feature class (or dataset) as opposed to the Parks and Recreation Natural Lands feature class (these small areas don't typically have high value as a 'natural' area).  Generally, Horticulture assets are not mowed but there may be occasional exceptions to this rule.  Horticulture assets may or may not include irrigation.  Tree grates are not included unless there are other plants in that space that require regular maintenance besides the tree alone.  Horticulture assets are mapped as polygons which provides a general maintenance area that is helpful in calculating time and costs associated with the asset depending on the level of service expected (mode of the park) and on the type of Horticulture asset.
